About

Hi! I am Marvin Stecker. I am pre-doctoral researcher at the Computational Communication Science Lab at the University of Vienna. I help to manage and contribute to the OPTED project which works towards establishing an infrastructure for the analysis of political texts in Europe.

While a communication scientist at heart, my background in sociology influences me to examine power structures, hiearchies and discrimination in politics and society. I investigate these topics, particulary their expression in (digital) media and culture, and connect them to topics such disinformation, political communiation and online discussions. Lastly, I am fascinated by questions around methodologies and epistemologies and how they intersect with research practices and the (re-)production of social inequalities, but also how these tools can be used to investigate these very phenomena.
I work with both qualitative and quantitive research methods, but I am especially interested in Computational Social Science. I’ve analysed texts with R, generated networks with Python and programmed turtles in NetLogo, but I will always dip my interested toes into what I need. Constantly on the lookout for fascinating new things to learn.

Equally, I am passionate about science education, skill-sharing and asking dumb questions. I love GIFs and StackOverflow and the kinds of examples that make use of a horse and three cucumbers. When I try anything new, I’ll inevitably fail 300 times, and then once more. If you read this, and you have a question, or are interested in something, or just wanna say hello, hit me up!

In my spare time, I enthusiastically gush about baroque music and proudly love cheap, no-name chocolate.

Marvin Stecker
